content.body: So I’m writing the intro of an MDN page for the Paint Timing API and want the intro the put the Paint Timing API on context relative to the Largest Contentful Paint API.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: So I’m writing the intro of an MDN page for the Paint Timing API and want the intro the put the Paint Timing API on context relative to the Largest Contentful Paint API.

content.body: Would it be accurate for me to make it basically say the Largest Contentful Paint API aims to provide timing information that’s more useful in practice, to the point that it obviates need for the Paint Timing API.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Would it be accurate for me to make it basically say the Largest Contentful Paint API aims to provide timing information that’s more useful in practice, to the point that it obviates need for the Paint Timing API.

content.body: In other words, implying (if not explicitly saying) that if you have access to the Largest Contentful Paint timing info, that’s better info and you wouldn’t also have use for knowing when first contentful paint occurred.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: In other words, implying (if not explicitly saying) that if you have access to the Largest Contentful Paint timing info, that’s better info and you wouldn’t also have use for knowing when first contentful paint occurred.

content.body: looks around for Noam Rosenthal

I have a vague recollection that during discussion with the WebKit team, they may have said that in their implementation, one of these paint-timing metrics wasn’t something that’s very useful in practice for developers to know. Or else, not something that their implementation doesn’t even make measurable such that it could be exposed to web content.

Or else, not something that their implementation doesn’t even make measurable such that it could be exposed to web content.

content.body: Chrome prioritizes LCP over FCP in Core Web Vitals. This was done based on some analysis and data showing that LCP captured user experience better. Perhaps that is what you're thinking of?
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Chrome prioritizes LCP over FCP in Core Web Vitals. This was done based on some analysis and data showing that LCP captured user experience better. Perhaps that is what you're thinking of?

content.body: Some discussion at the intro to https://web.dev/lcp/, but not much... maybe there's a better source.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: Some discussion at the intro to https://web.dev/lcp/, but not much... maybe there's a better source.

content.body: I think FCP are LCP are both useful, in different ways and depending on the content
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: I think FCP are LCP are both useful, in different ways and depending on the content

content.body: they are two important points in the loading experience. LCP is more important for CWV but both can give the developers a good hint about how your loading went
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: they are two important points in the loading experience. LCP is more important for CWV but both can give the developers a good hint about how your loading went

content.body: e.g. if you have a small "Loading" icon and then all the real content loads, FCP will give you the time of the loading icon and LCP will give you the time of the entire content
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: e.g. if you have a small "Loading" icon and then all the real content loads, FCP will give you the time of the loading icon and LCP will give you the time of the entire content

content.body: for pages like wikipedia, FCP is very important - it's the time where the wikipedia content loads. Afterwards maybe some big image would load and be the LCP, but both timings are meaningful. So like I said it's content-dependent
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: for pages like wikipedia, FCP is very important - it's the time where the wikipedia content loads. Afterwards maybe some big image would load and be the LCP, but both timings are meaningful. So like I said it's content-dependent

content.body: CWV is an attempt to crystalize all the different metrics to 3 magic numbers, but many times you need more metrics than that to get the whole story and optimize
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: CWV is an attempt to crystalize all the different metrics to 3 magic numbers, but many times you need more metrics than that to get the whole story and optimize

content.body: sideshowbarker: the webkit team discussion was about `first-paint`. They didn't want to include it because it was not useful given that webkit buffers painting until it's contentful
content.formatted_body: sideshowbarker: the webkit team discussion was about first-paint. They didn't want to include it because it was not useful given that webkit buffers painting until it's contentful

content.body:
> <@zcorpan_:matrix.org> hsivonen: https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/iframe-embed-object.html#the-iframe-element:process-the-iframe-attributes-3

Thanks. I observe that `object` doesn't have a similar _initialInsertion_ flag. Not sure yet, if this is a spec oversight or a genuine platform difference between `object` and `iframe`.
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @zcorpan_:matrix.org
hsivonen: https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/iframe-embed-object.html#the-iframe-element:process-the-iframe-attributes-3
Thanks. I observe that object doesn't have a similar initialInsertion flag. Not sure yet, if this is a spec oversight or a genuine platform difference between object and iframe.

In reply to @zcorpan_:matrix.org

Thanks. I observe that object doesn't have a similar initialInsertion flag. Not sure yet, if this is a spec oversight or a genuine platform difference between object and iframe.
